newsitem.title: GERMANY: Kinkel says Franco-German EMU motor in good order.
newsitem.headline: Kinkel says Franco-German EMU motor in good order.

text.p: German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel said the Franco-German motor behind European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) was in good order and complained it was being portrayed too negatively.

In an interview with the General Anzeiger newspaper released ahead of publication on Wednesday, Kinkel said the two countries remained at the heart of efforts toward European integration despite recent differences.

German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French Prime Minister Lionel Jospin are to meet later this month in Bonn to clear the air in relations in what could be a decisive step on the road to a single European currency.
Commentators say relations between Bonn and Paris have deteriorated since the election victory for France's Socialists in June.

"We must fight this image. You can talk -- or write -- yourself into a crisis," Kinkel said. "Bonn and Paris know they are in emotional and rational terms the most important partners. That's how it is and that's how it's staying."

Kinkel declined to be drawn into speculation about France's chances of fulfilling a key criterion of entry to EMU -- that its budget deficit not exceed three percent of gross domestic product (GDP). Analysts say those chances are looking increasingly slim.
But he reiterated Bonn's position that France was doing its best to put its finances in order to qualify for the 1999 launch of Europe's planned single currency, the euro.
Kohl and Jospin meet on August 28 in Bonn to try to overcome strains between two countries, which pride themselves on working together as the motor of European integration.
The French left's election victory on June 1 has raised doubts about Paris' willingness to make more budget sacrifices for the euro.

France and Germany differed over adding a chapter on employment to the Maastricht Treaty at the June EU summit, but Kinkel said the conflict could have been much worse if they had not sought to minimise difficulties.
"The new French government promised in its election campaign to launch a state funding programme for employment policies," Kinkel said.
Bonn sought a compromise in the end by agreeing to add the jobs chapter but rejected extra spending on job-creation schemes.
"We tried to minimise a potentially big confrontation. We did the best we could in Amsterdam," Kinkel said. REUTER
